revision.comment: Add romanization and update change history
revision.text:
{{main|ISO 3166-2}} '''ISO 3166-2:DJ''' is the entry for [[Djibouti]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivisions]] (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|states]]) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]]. Currently for Djibouti, ISO 3166-2 codes are defined for [[regions of Djibouti|5 regions and 1 city]]. The city [[Djibouti (city)|Djibouti]] is the capital of the country and has special status equal to the regions. Each code consists of two parts, separated by a hyphen. The first part is {{mono|DJ}}, the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code of Djibouti. The second part is two letters. ==Current codes== Subdivision names are listed as in the ISO 3166-2 standard published by the ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency (ISO 3166/MA). [[ISO 639-1]] codes are used to represent subdivision names in the following [[official language|administrative languages]]: * (fr): [[French language|French]] * (ar): [[Arabic language|Arabic]] ''Click on the button in the header to sort each column.'' {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Code ! Subdivision name ([[French language|fr]]) ! Subdivision name ([[Arabic language|ar]])
(BGN/PCGN 1956) ! Subdivision category |- | {{mono|DJ-AS}} | [[Ali Sabieh Region|Ali Sabieh]] | ‘Alī Şabīḩ | region |- | {{mono|DJ-AR}} | [[Arta Region|Arta]] | ‘Artā | region |- | {{mono|DJ-DI}} | [[Dikhil Region|Dikhil]] | Dikhīl | region |- | {{mono|DJ-OB}} | [[Obock Region|Obock]] | Awbūk | region |- | {{mono|DJ-TA}} | [[Tadjourah Region|Tadjourah]] | Tājūrah | region |- | {{mono|DJ-DJ}} | [[Djibouti (city)|Djibouti]] | Jībūtī | city |} ==Changes== The following changes to the entry have been announced by the ISO 3166/MA since the first publication of ISO 3166-2 in 1998. ISO stopped issuing newsletters in 2013. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Newsletter ! Date issued ! Description of change in newsletter ! Code/Subdivision change |- | id="I-7" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-2_newsletter_i-7_en.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter I-7}}] | {{nowrap|2005-09-13}} | Change of generic term for administrative divisions. Addition of new region "Arta". New list source and code source | style=white-space:nowrap | '''Subdivisions added:'''
{{mono|DJ-AR}} [[Arta Region|Arta]] |- | id="II-3" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-2_newsletter_ii-3_2011-12-13.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter II-3}}] | {{nowrap|2011-12-13}}
''(corrected
{{nowrap|2011-12-15}})'' | Language adjustment and source list update. | |- | rowspan="3" | [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:DJ Online Browsing
Platform (OBP)] | 2014-11-03 | Update List Source | |- | 2015-11-27 | Add romanization system for Arabic; typographical correction of DJ-AS; update List Source | |- | 2016-11-15 | Change of spelling of DJ-OB in ara | |} ==See also== * [[Subdivisions of Djibouti]] * [[List of FIPS region codes (D-F)#DJ: Djibouti|FIPS region codes of Djibouti]] ==External links== * [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:DJ ISO Online Browsing Platform: DJ] * [http://www.statoids.com/udj.html Regions of Djibouti], Statoids.com {{ISO 3166}} [[Category:ISO 3166|2:DJ]] [[Category:Regions of Djibouti|*ISO 3166-2]] [[Category:Djibouti-related lists]]

revision.text:
{{main|ISO 3166-2}} '''ISO 3166-2:PK''' is the entry for [[Pakistan]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]]. Currently for Pakistan, ISO 3166-2 codes are defined for [[administrative units of Pakistan|1 federal capital territory, 4 provinces, 1 territory, and 2 Pakistan administered areas]]. The [[Islamabad Capital Territory]] contains the capital of the country [[Islamabad]] and has special status equal to the provinces and territory. Each code consists of two parts, separated by a hyphen. The first part is {{mono|PK}}, the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code of Pakistan. The second part is two letters. ==Current codes== Subdivision names are listed as in the ISO 3166-2 standard published by the ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency (ISO 3166/MA). [[ISO 639-1]] codes are used to represent subdivision names in the following [[official language|administrative language]]s: * (en): [[English language|English]] * (ur): [[Urdu language|Urdu]] ''Click on the button in the header to sort each column.'' {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Code ! Subdivision name ([[English language|en]]) ! Subdivision name ([[Urdu language|ur]])
(BGN/PCGN 2007) ! Subdivision category |- | {{mono|PK-IS}} | [[Islamabad Capital Territory|Islamabad]] | Islāmābād | federal capital territory |- | {{mono|PK-BA}} | [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan]] | Balōchistān | province |- | {{mono|PK-KP}} | [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] | Khaībar Pakhtūnkhwā | province |- | {{mono|PK-PB}} | [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]] | Panjāb | province |- | {{mono|PK-SD}} | [[Sindh]] | Sindh | province |- | {{mono|PK-TA}} | [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas]] | | territory |- | {{mono|PK-JK}} | [[Azad Kashmir|Azad Jammu and Kashmir]]
(local variant is AJ&K) | Āzād Jammūñ o Kashmīr | Pakistan administered area |- | {{mono|PK-GB}} | [[Gilgit-Baltistan]] | Gilgit-Baltistān | Pakistan administered area |} ==Changes== The following changes to the entry have been announced in newsletters by the ISO 3166/MA since the first publication of ISO 3166-2 in 1998: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Newsletter ! Date issued ! Description of change in newsletter ! Code/Subdivision change |- | id="II-3" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-2_newsletter_ii-3_2011-12-13.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter II-3}}] | {{nowrap|2011-12-13}}
''(corrected
{{nowrap|2011-12-15}})'' | Name change, language readjustment and source list update. | style=white-space:nowrap | '''Codes:'''
{{mono|PK-NW}} North-West Frontier → {{mono|PK-KP}} [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]]
{{mono|PK-NA}} Northern Areas → {{mono|PK-GB}} [[Gilgit-Baltistan]] |- | rowspan="2" | [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:PK Online Browsing
Platform (OBP)] | 2015-11-27 | Addition of romanization system for urd | |- | 2017-11-23 | Change of spelling of category name from ilaqa to ‘alāqahilaqa, from suba to sūbah, from wafaqi dar-ul-hakumat ka ilaqa to wafāqī dār al ḩikūmat ‘alāqah; change of subdivision name of PK-JK (eng & urd); addition of local variation of PK-JK in eng; update List Source | ''(TBD)'' |} ==See also== * [[Administrative units of Pakistan]] * [[List of FIPS region codes (P-R)#PK: Pakistan|FIPS region codes of Pakistan]] ==External links== * [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:PK ISO Online Browsing Platform: PK] * [http://www.statoids.com/upk.html Provinces of Pakistan], Statoids.com {{ISO 3166}} [[Category:ISO 3166|2:PK]] [[Category:Subdivisions of Pakistan|*ISO 3166-2]] [[Category:Administrative units of Pakistan-related lists]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox officeholder |name=Leung Wai-tung |native_name={{nobold|梁煒彤}} | honorific-suffix = [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]], [[Justice of Peace|JP]] |image= |birth_date={{birth year and age|1946}} |birth_place= Hong Kong |office=Member of the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong|Legislative Council]] |term_start=2 October 1988 |term_end=22 August 1991 |appointed= [[David Clive Wilson|Sir David Wilson]] |predecessor= |successor= |alma_mater= [[Belilios Public School]]
[[University of Hong Kong]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[MPhil]]) |occupation= University lecturer |party= [[Hong Kong Democratic Foundation|Democratic Foundation]] (1989–91) |death_place = |citizenship = |spouse = |relations = |children = |portfolio = |religion = }} '''Diana Leung Wai-tung''', [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]], [[Justice of Peace|JP]] ({{zh-t|梁煒彤}}; born 1946) is a former member of the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]]. ==Biography== Leung studied at the [[Belilios Public School]] and attend the [[University of Hong Kong]], obtained her bachelor's degree in geography and geology in 1968 and master's degree in urban geography in 1973. She worked as a lecturer at Department of Geography and Geology at [[Hong Kong University]].{{cite web|title=Database on LegCo members|url=http://app.legco.gov.hk/member_front/english/library/member_detail.aspx?id=133|accessdate=4 May 2013|work=Legislative Council of Hong Kong}} She was appointed to the Legislative Council by Governor [[David Clive Wilson|David Wilson]] in 1988. She and [[Edward Leong]] and [[Jimmy McGregor]], two other legislators, launched the [[Hong Kong Democratic Foundation]] in 1989 and Leung served as the founding vice-chairperson, which was seen as pro-democratic liberal political group at the time. She was one of the only three appointed members who affiliated with political organisation (the other two being [[Maria Tam]] and [[Lau Wong-fat]]).{{cite book|title=Other Hong Kong Report 1991|first=Anthony|last=Lawrence|year=1991|page=72|publisher=Chinese University Press}} She soon quit the foundation citing her difference with the mainstream members. She was considered as radical among the majority of the appointed and pro-government legislative councillors, as she and [[Szeto Wah]] urged for repealing the government's regulation of political activities in schools, instead of moderating as the government revised on the Education (Amendment) Bill.{{cite book|title=Education in Hong Kong, 1941 to 2001: Visions and Revisions|first=Anthony|last=Sweeting|page=398|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|year=2004}} She was also the only appointed member to vote against the Trade Description Amendment Bill of 1991, a bill that sparked criticism from labour groups. She was also the member of the [[Hong Kong Housing Authority]] from 1985 until her resignation on 5 November 1996. She was one of the six female candidates in the [[Hong Kong legislative election, 1991|1991 Legislative Council election]], the first ever direct election in the territory but was defeated by the candidates from the [[United Democrats of Hong Kong]], notably [[Martin Lee]] in [[Hong Kong Island East (constituency)|Hong Kong Island East]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Leung, Wai-tung}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hong Kong academics]] [[Category:Hong Kong geographers]] [[Category:Hong Kong educators]] [[Category:Hong Kong women in politics]] [[Category:Hong Kong Democratic Foundation politicians]] [[Category:Members of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Members of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong]] [[Category:District councillors of Kowloon City District]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Hong Kong]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Hong Kong]] [[Category:HK LegCo Members 1988–91]]

page.title: List of Latin place names in Britain

revision.comment: /* Island names */Improving links and other minor cleanup tasks
revision.text:
{{Latin place names}}
This list includes places in [[Great Britain]] (including neighbouring islands such as the [[Isle of Man]]), some of which were part of the [[Roman Empire]], or were later given [[Latin]] place names in [[historical]] [[Reference work|references]].
==Background== Until the [[Modern Era]], [[Latin]] was the [[Lingua franca|common language]] for [[scholarship]] and [[Cartography|mapmaking]]. During the 19th and 20th centuries, [[Germany|German]] scholars in particular have made significant contributions to the study of historical place names, or ''Ortsnamenkunde''. These studies have, in turn, contributed to the study of [[genealogy]]. For genealogists and historians of pre-Modern Europe, knowing alternative names of places is vital to extracting information from both public and private records. Even specialists in this field point out, however, that the information can be easily taken out of context, since there is a great deal of repetition of place names throughout Europe; reliance purely on apparent connections should therefore be tempered with valid historical methodology.
==Caveats and notes== Latin place names are not always exclusive to one place — for example, there were several Roman cities whose names began with ''Colonia'' and then a more descriptive term. During the [[Middle Ages]], these were often shortened to just ''Colonia''. One of these, ''Colonia Agrippinensis'', retains the name today in the form of [[Cologne]] (from French, German Köln).
Early sources for [[ancient Rome|Roman]] names show numerous variants and spellings of the [[Latin]] names.
The modern canonical name is listed first. Sources are listed chronologically. In general, only the earliest source is shown for each name, although many of the names are recorded in more than one of the sources. Where the source differs in spelling, or has other alternatives, these are listed following the source. As an aid to searching, variants are spelled completely, and listed in most likely chronology.
Superscripts indicate: # Latinized form of the Greek-derived name. # Latinized form of the Asian-derived name via Greek. # Altered Latinized form of the Greek-derived name.
'?' probably historical mistake
==Cities and towns in England== [[File:Roman britain 400.jpg|thumb|right|400px|Roman Britain in 400 AD]]
{| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3" ! Canonical Latin Name (source(s): variant(s)) !! English Name (native language(s)) - older name(s), (other language(s)), location(s) |- | [[Aquae Arnemetiae]] || [[Buxton]] |- | [[Aquae Sulis]] || [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]] |- | [[Bremetennacum]] || [[Ribchester]] |- | [[Camulodunum]] || [[Colchester]] |- | Cantabrigia <small>(medieval Latinisation)</small> || [[Cambridge]] |- | [[Cataractonium]] || [[Catterick, North Yorkshire|Catterick]] |- | [[Coria (Corbridge)|Coria]], Corspitium || [[Corbridge]] |- | [[Corinium]] || [[Cirencester]] |- | [[Deva Victrix|Deva]] || [[Chester]] |- | Dunelmum<ref>Also other spellings</ref> || [[Durham, England|Durham]] |- | [[Durnovaria]] || [[Dorchester, Dorset|Dorchester]] |- | Durocobrivis || [[Dunstable]] |- | [[Durovernum Cantiacorum]], Cantuaria || [[Canterbury]] |- | [[Eboracum]] || [[York]] |- | [[Glevum]] || [[Gloucester]] |- | [[Isca Dumnoniorum]] || [[Exeter]] |- | [[Isurium Brigantum]] || [[Aldborough, North Yorkshire|Aldborough]] |- | [[Lindinis]] || [[Ilchester]] |- | [[Lindum Colonia]] || [[Lincoln, Lincolnshire|Lincoln]] |- | [[Londinium]] || [[London]] |- | Londonia || [[London]] |- | [[Luguvalium]] || [[Carlisle, Cumbria|Carlisle]] |- | Mamucium, Mancunium<ref>"Mancunium" derives from an early misspelling of the Roman name.</ref> || [[Manchester]] |- | [[Noviomagus Reginorum]] || [[Chichester]] |- | Oxonium, Oxonia || [[Oxford]] |- | [[Petuaria]] || [[Brough, East Riding of Yorkshire|Brough]] |- | [[Pons Aelius]] || [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] |- | [[Ratae Corieltauvorum]] || [[Leicester]] |- | [[Venta Belgarum]] || [[Winchester]] |- | [[Verulamium]] || [[St Albans]] |- | [[Viroconium Cornoviorum]] || [[Wroxeter]] |}
==Cities and towns in Scotland==
{| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3" ! Canonical Latin name (source(s): variant(s)) !! English name (native language(s)) – older name(s), (other language(s)), location(s) |- | Andreanae (HLU:<ref name=HJJLU>'''HLU''': [[Hofmann, Johann Jacob]] (1635–1706): ''Lexicon Universale''</ref> Kirkruel?,<ref>'?' probably historical mistake</ref> Reguli Fanum, Andreopolis; GOL:<ref name=GOL>'''GOL''': The standard reference to Latin placenames, with their modern equivalents, is [[Johann Georg Theodor Grässe|Dr. J. G. Th. Grässe]], ''[[Orbis Latinus|Orbis Latinus: Lexikon lateinischer geographischer Namen des Mittelalters und der Neuzeit]]'' (1861), an exhaustive work of meticulous German scholarship that is available on-line in the second edition of 1909. To use it, one must understand German names of countries, as they were in 1909. The original was re-edited and expanded in a multi-volume edition in 1972.</ref> Sanctae Andreae Coenobium), Kirkrule, Kilrule || [[St Andrews]] |- | Devana (2PG2;<ref name=2PG2>'''2PG2''': [[Ptolemy]] (Claudius Ptolemaeus), ''[[Ptolemy#Geography|Geographia]]''; book "PG" chapter (that is, "2PG2" instead of the usual "II.2"). Ptolemy wrote in [[Greek language|Greek]], so names are [[transliteration|transliterated]] back into [[Latin]] to reveal the original form.</ref> HLU:<ref name=HJJLU/> Aberdonia, Aberdona, Verniconam; GOL:<ref name=GOL/> Aberdonum, Aberdonium, Abredonia), Devanha || [[Aberdeen]] |- | Dunedinum (BSH:<ref name=BSH>'''BSH''': [[Buchanan, George]] (1506–1582): ''Rerum Scoticarum Historia'' (1582)</ref> Edinburgum, Edinum; GOL:<ref name=GOL/> Edimburgum, Edenburgum, Alata castra, Alatius burgus, Aneda, Puellarum castra) || [[Edinburgh]] |- | Glascouium (GOL:<ref name=GOL/> Glascovia, Glascum, Glascua, Glasgua) || [[Glasgow]] |- | [[Trimontium (Newstead)|Trimontium]] || [[Newstead, Scottish Borders|Newstead]] |}
==Cities and towns in Wales==

English name (native language(s)) - older name(s), (other language(s)), location(s) |- | Alabum || [[Llandovery]] |- | Bangertium<ref name=GOL/> || [[Bangor, Wales|Bangor]] |- | Blestium, Monemuta || [[Monmouth]] |- | Bovium || [[Cowbridge]] ''(disputed)'' |- | Burrium || [[Usk]] |- | Cambria ||[[Wales]] |- | Canovium || [[Caerhun]] |- | Castra Diva || [[Chester]] |- | Cicutio || [[Pumsaint]] |- | Gobannium || [[Abergavenny]] |- | Isca Silurum (AI:<ref name=Antonine>'''AI''': [[Antonine Itinerary]]</ref> Isca, Iscae; RC:<ref name=Ravenna>'''RC''': [[Ravenna Cosmography]], ''Ravennatis Anonymi Cosmographia''</ref> Isca Augusta; GOL:<ref name=GOL/> Isca Legio), Castra Legionis || [[Caerleon]] |- | Moridunum || [[Carmarthen]] |- | Mediomanum || [[Caersws]] |- | Nidum || [[Neath]] |- | [[Segontium Roman Fort|Segontium]] (AI:<ref name=Antonine/> Segontio; RC:<ref name=Ravenna/> Seguntio; GOL:<ref name=GOL/> Seguntium) || [[Caernarfon]] |- | Venta Silurum || [[Caerwent]] |}
==Island names==

English name (native language(s)) - older name(s), (other language(s)), location(s) |- |Malaeus<ref name=2PG1>'''2PG1''': [[Ptolemy]] (Claudius Ptolemaeus), ''[[Ptolemy#Geography|Geographia]]''; book "PG" chapter (that is, "2PG1" instead of the usual "II.1"). Ptolemy wrote in [[Greek language|Greek]], so names are [[transliteration|transliterated]] back into [[Latin]] to reveal the original form</ref> ||[[Isle of Mull|Mull]] |- |Mona<ref name=2PG1/> ||[[Anglesey]] |- |Monaoeda<ref name=2PG1/> ||[[Isle of Man]] |- |Orcades<ref name=2PG2/> ||[[Orkney]] |- |Scetis<ref name=2PG2/> ||[[Isle of Skye|Skye]] |- |Taniatide<ref name=Ravenna/> ||[[Thanet District|Thanet]] |- |Vectis<ref name=2PG2/> ||[[Isle of Wight]] |- |Caesar<ref name=2PG1/> ||[[Jersey]] |}
==Region or country names==
{| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3" ! Canonical Latin name (source(s): variant(s)) !! English name (native language(s)) – older name(s), (other language(s)), location(s) |- |Albion<ref name=2PG2/><ref name=Tacitus>[[Tacitus]] (Gaius Cornelius Tacitus), ''[[Agricola (book)|Agricola]]''</ref> || [[Great Britain]] |- |Anglia || [[England]] |- |Britannia<ref name=2PG2/><ref name=Tacitus/> || [[Great Britain]] |- |Caledonia<ref name=2PG2/><ref name=Tacitus/> || [[Scotland]] |- |Cambria || [[Wales]] |- |Cornubia || [[Cornwall]] |- |Hibernia<ref name=2PG1/>|| [[Ireland]] |- |Orientalium Anglorum || [[East Anglia]] |- |Scotia || [[Scotland]], and formerly [[Ireland]] |- |Salopia |Shropshire |}
==See also== * [[List of Roman place names in Britain]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Sources== In order of likely publication:
*'''TA''': [[Tacitus]] (Gaius Cornelius Tacitus), ''[[Agricola (book)|Agricola]]'' *'''PNH''': [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]] (Gaius Plinius Secundus), ''[[Pliny's Natural History|Naturalis Historia]]''; book "PNH" chapter (that is, "37PNH81" instead of the usual "N.H.xxxvii.81"). *'''PG''': [[Ptolemy]] (Claudius Ptolemaeus), ''[[Ptolemy#Geography|Geographia]]''; book "PG" chapter (that is, "2PG3" instead of the usual "II.3"). Ptolemy wrote in [[Greek language|Greek]], so names are [[transliteration|transliterated]] back into [[Latin]] to reveal the original form. *'''AI''': [[Antonine Itinerary]] *'''ND''': ''[[Notitia Dignitatum]]'' *'''RC''': [[Ravenna Cosmography]], ''Ravennatis Anonymi Cosmographia'' *'''BSH''': [[Buchanan, George]] (1506–1582): ''Rerum Scoticarum Historia'' (1582) *'''HLU''': [[Hofmann, Johann Jacob]] (1635–1706): ''Lexicon Universale'' *'''HD1851''': Rejected by modern historians, but seen in this document from 1851 - [http://www.historicaldirectories.org/hd/PAGEVIEWER.ASP?fn=00006QL8.TIF&dn=LUL2002tif&zoom=in] and [http://www.historicaldirectories.org/hd/PAGEVIEWER.ASP?fn=00006ql9.tif&dn=LUL2002tif&zoom=in] (<small>bottom of one page to top of next</small>) *'''GOL''': The standard reference to Latin placenames, with their modern equivalents, is [[Johann Georg Theodor Grässe|Dr. J. G. Th. Grässe]], ''[[Orbis Latinus|Orbis Latinus : Lexikon lateinischer geographischer Namen des Mittelalters und der Neuzeit]]'' (1861), an exhaustive work of meticulous German scholarship that is available on-line in the second edition of 1909. To use it, one must understand German names of countries, as they were in 1909. The original was re-edited and expanded in a multi-volume edition in 1972. *A.L.F. Rivet and Colin Smith, ''The place-names of Roman Britain'', London, 1979 (reprinted by Book Club Associates, 1981).
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100506231742/http://www.roman-britain.org/geography/itinerary.htm Antonine Itinerary] *[http://philological.bham.ac.uk/scothist/ Buchanan, Rerum Scoticarum Historia] *[http://www.bayerische-landesbibliothek-online.de/orbis-latinus Grässe, Orbis Latinus] *[http://www.columbia.edu/acis/ets/Graesse/contents.html Grässe, Orbis Latinus] *[http://historicaldirectories.org/ Historical Directories, England and Wales, from 1750 to 1919] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100525214748/http://www.uni-mannheim.de/mateo/camenaref/hofmann.html Hofmann: Lexicon Universale] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100613065047/http://roman-britain.org/notitia.htm Notitia Dignitatum: The British Section] *[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Pliny_the_Elder/home.html Pliny the Elder: the Natural History] *[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Gazetteer/Periods/Roman/_Texts/Ptolemy/home.html Ptolemy: the Geography] *[http://romanmap.com/ Roman Map of Britain] *[http://members.aol.com/antoninus1/piety/agricola.htm Tacitus: Agricola (English)] *[http://www.ipa.net/~magreyn#Record�Interpreter List of Latin placenames in Britain]
{{Europefooter}} {{Place name etymologies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Latin Place Names In Britain}} [[Category:Alternative names of European places|Latin in Britain]] [[Category:British toponymy|Latin place names]] [[Category:Lists of Latin place names|Britain]] [[Category:Lists of cities by toponymy|Latin, North Atlantic]] [[Category:Lists of cities in Europe|Britain]] [[Category:Lists of places in the United Kingdom|Latin names]] [[Category:Roman Britain-related lists|Latin place names]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} [[File:Tenby Lifeboat sheds - geograph.org.uk - 242734.jpg|thumb|All weather lifeboat station with a slipway for launching.]] [[File:Lifeboat Station - Porthcawl - geograph.org.uk - 1400792.jpg|thumb|Inshore lifeboat station, which uses a carriage to launch lifeboats.]] '''Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) stations''' are the bases for the [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|RNLI]]'s fleet of search and rescue [[Lifeboat (rescue)|lifeboats]] that cover the coastal waters around the entire [[British Isles]], as well as major inland waterways. The service was established in 1824 and is operated largely by volunteers. Its headquarters are at [[Poole]], [[Dorset]] and it is a registered charity in both the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Republic of Ireland]]. == Key == === Lifeboat types === {{Main|Royal National Lifeboat Institution lifeboats}} The types of boats provided at each station and the launching methods vary depending on local needs. If more than one boat is provided they are sometimes stationed in separate buildings at different locations in the same town. RNLI boats fall into three broad groups: * All weather lifeboats (ALBs): {{Lbb|Mersey}}, {{Lbb|Severn}}, {{Lbb|Shannon}}, {{Lbb|Tamar}}, {{Lbb|Trent}} and {{Lbb|Tyne}} * Inshore lifeboats (ILBs): {{Lbc|D|IB1}}, {{Lbb|Atlantic 75}}, {{Lbb|Atlantic 85}} and {{Lbc|E}} * Hovercraft: [[RNLI hovercraft lifeboat|''H''-class]] === Launch methods === [[File:Minehead - launching D-712 (2).jpg|thumb|'Tooltrack' tractor launching an inshore lifeboat at {{lbs|Minehead}}]] The principal launching methods are: * Carriage – an ALB or ILB is pushed into the water on a carriage by a tractor * Davit – an ILB is lowered into the water by a crane * Launchway – an ILB is pushed into the water on a carriage by hand * Moored afloat – an ALB or ILB is kept in the water alongside the lifeboat station or nearby, in which case a small boarding boat is provided so that the crew can reach it. * Slipway – an ALB slides down a slipway straight into the water. * Transporter – hovercraft are kept on the rear of trucks that can transport and offload them anywhere === Divisions === The following lists do not include the lifeguard patrolled beaches which also have their own equipment including [[Arancia-class lifeboat|inflatable boats]] and [[jetski]]s. The information is correct to 2009 unless noted otherwise,{{cite book |last= Denton |first= Tony |title= Handbook 2009 |year= 2009 |publisher= Lifeboat Enthusiasts Society |location= Shrewsbury |pages= 66–71 }} and is set out like the RNLI's divisional model. As far as possible it follows a clockwise route around the coast. * East Division – [[East Anglia]] and South East England * South Division – South West England and the [[Channel Islands]] * West Division – [[Wales]] and the [[Isle of Man]] * North Division – East and west coasts of northern England * Scotland Division – [[Scotland]] * Ireland Division – [[Republic of Ireland]] and [[Northern Ireland]] == List of stations by division == === East Division === {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- ! width="18%" | Station ! width="22%" | Location ! width="12%" | Lifeboat type(s) ! width="12%" | Launch method ! page.title: List of metropolitan areas in Sweden

revision.comment: edit
revision.text:
[[Sweden]] has three metropolitan areas consisting of the areas surrounding the three largest cities, [[Stockholm]], [[Gothenburg]] and [[Malmö]].[http://www.scb.se/Grupp/Hitta_statistik/Regional%20statistik/Indelningar/_Dokument/Storstadsomr.pdf SCB Statistics Sweden – Definition of Metropolitan Areas in Sweden published in 2005] The statistics have been retrieved from [[Statistics Sweden]] and the statistics released November 10, 2014.[http://www.scb.se/sv_/Hitta-statistik/Statistik-efter-amne/Befolkning/Befolkningens-sammansattning/Befolkningsstatistik/25788/25795/Kvartals--och-halvarsstatistik---Kommun-lan-och-riket/378570/ SCB Statistics Sweden - Population Statistics published November 10, 2014 ''(only available in Swedish)''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141111032147/http://www.scb.se/sv_/Hitta-statistik/Statistik-efter-amne/Befolkning/Befolkningens-sammansattning/Befolkningsstatistik/25788/25795/Kvartals--och-halvarsstatistik---Kommun-lan-och-riket/378570/ |date=November 11, 2014 }} The official land area for each municipality have also been retrieved from [[Statistics Sweden]], the agency that defines these areas.[http://www.scb.se/sv_/Hitta-statistik/Statistikdatabasen/Variabelvaljare/?px_tableid=ssd_extern%3aAreal2012&rxid=87a2177f-7ffc-49c9-b4f1-227fd7230618 SCB Statistics Sweden - Official Land Area per Municipality, retrieved February 24, 2014 ''(only available in Swedish)''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140118013112/http://www.scb.se/sv_/Hitta-statistik/Statistikdatabasen/Variabelvaljare/?px_tableid=ssd_extern%3aAreal2012&rxid=87a2177f-7ffc-49c9-b4f1-227fd7230618 |date=January 18, 2014 }} ==Metropolitan Stockholm== [[File:Metropolitan Stockholm ver.2.PNG|right|thumb|350px]] [[File:GamlaStan from Katarinahissen Stockholm Swe.jpg|right|thumb|350px|Central Stockholm and Old Town]] '''Metropolitan Stockholm''' (also known as Greater Stockholm or, in Swedish, ''Storstockholm''), is a [[metropolitan area]] surrounding the Swedish capital of Stockholm. Since 2005, Metropolitan Stockholm is defined by official Swedish Statistics as all of [[Stockholm County]].[http://www.scb.se/statistik/_publikationer/OV9999_2004A01_BR_X20OP0502.pdf SCB Statistics Sweden – Regional Divisions in Sweden published in 2005] It is the largest of the three metropolitan areas in Sweden. Metropolitan Stockholm is divided into 5 areas: [[Stockholm City Centre]], [[Söderort]], [[Västerort]] of [[Stockholm Municipality]]; and the northern suburbs and southern suburbs, which consists of several municipalities. ===Statistics=== {| class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align:right" |-bgcolor=#dddddd ! Municipality !! Number !! Population !! Area{{Ref label|1|1}}!! Density{{Ref label|2|2}}!!Part |-align=right bgcolor=#ddddff |align=left|[[Stockholm Municipality|Stockholm]]||1||914,909||187.17||4,861.76 |align=right|''[[Stockholm City Centre|Centre]], [[West Stockholm|West]], [[South Stockholm|South]]'' |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Huddinge Municipality|Huddinge]]||2||104,353||131.01||795.01 |align=left valign=top rowspan=9|''Southern Suburbs
([[Södermanland]])'' |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Botkyrka Municipality|Botkyrka]]||3||89,142||194.17||451.05 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Salem Municipality|Salem]]||4||16,201||54.09||297.76 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Södertälje Municipality|Södertälje]]||5||92,490||525.15||175.18 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Nykvarn Municipality|Nykvarn]]||6||9,862||152.76||63.52 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Nynäshamn Municipality|Nynäshamn]]||7||27,168||358.76||75.16 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Haninge Municipality|Haninge]]||8||82,676||458.07||179.04 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Tyresö Municipality|Tyresö]]||9||45,629||69.25||651.94 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Nacka Municipality|Nacka]]||10||96,420||95.12||1,005.61 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Värmdö Municipality|Värmdö]]||11||40,660||448.03||89.91 |align=left valign=top rowspan=16|''Northern Suburbs
([[Uppland]])'' |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Lidingö Municipality|Lidingö]]||12||45,598||30.80||1,476.23 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Vaxholm Municipality|Vaxholm]]||13||11,385||57.88||195.51 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Österåker Municipality|Österåker]]||14||41,317||312.40||131.33 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Norrtälje Municipality|Norrtälje]]||15||57,694||2016.04||28.50 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Vallentuna Municipality|Vallentuna]]||16||32,008||358.36||88.96 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Sigtuna Municipality|Sigtuna]]||17||44,174||327.40||134.46 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Upplands-Bro Municipality|Upplands-Bro]]||18||25,370||235.47||107.15 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Upplands Väsby Municipality|Upplands Väsby]]||19||41,883||75.09||556.49 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Täby Municipality|Täby]]||20||67,519||60.72||1,109.24 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Sollentuna Municipality|Sollentuna]]||21||69,525||52.64||1,314.27 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Danderyd Municipality|Danderyd]]||22||32,286||26.40||1,222.01 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Järfälla Municipality|Järfälla]]||23||71,130||53.81||1,306.11 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Ekerö Municipality|Ekerö]]||24||26,770||217.68||122.30 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Sundbyberg Municipality|Sundbyberg]]||25||44,663||8.67||5,047.64 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd |align=left|[[Solna Municipality|Solna]]||26||74,273||19.30||3,834.77 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffdddd !align=left|Total!!26!!2,205,105!!6,526.24!!335.94||align=left|''Metropolitan Area
'' |} {{note label|1|1}} km2
{{note label|2|2}} Population per km2 ==Metropolitan Gothenburg== [[File:Metropolitan Gothenburg ver.3.PNG|right|thumb|350px]] [[File:Gothenburg, Sweden, from the Älsborgs Bridge.jpg|right|thumb|350px|Central Gothenburg and the harbor, the largest in the Nordic Region]] '''Metropolitan Gothenburg''' (''Storgöteborg'' or literally Greater Gothenburg), is a metropolitan area surrounding the city of [[Gothenburg]] in [[Sweden]]. The metropolitan region is located in [[Västra Götaland County]], except for the [[Municipalities of Sweden|municipality]] of [[Kungsbacka Municipality|Kungsbacka]], which is located to the south in [[Halland County]]. As of 2005, the municipalities of [[Alingsås Municipality|Alingsås]] and [[Lilla Edet Municipality|Lilla Edet]] were added to the region. The region is often used for statistical measures, and estimates in the 1960s predicted that the region would have about one million inhabitants in the year 2000. The region is the second largest metropolitan area in Sweden after [[Metropolitan Stockholm]]. ===Statistics=== {| class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align:right" |-bgcolor=#dddddd ! Municipality !! Number !! Population !! Area{{Ref label|3|1}}!! Density{{Ref label|4|2}} |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Gothenburg Municipality|Gothenburg]]||1||565,496 |447.76||1,206.30 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Mölndal Municipality|Mölndal]]||2||66,733||145.84||430.05 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Partille Municipality|Partille]]||3||37,931||56.83||641.62 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Härryda Municipality|Härryda]]||4||37,430||266.78||135.83 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Lerum Municipality|Lerum]]||5||41,660||258.61||153.50 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Ale Municipality|Ale]]||6||30,399||316.51||89.54 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Kungälv Municipality|Kungälv]]||7||44,312||362.59||116.64 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Öckerö Municipality|Öckerö]]||8||12,930||25.74||490.09 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Tjörn Municipality|Tjörn]]||9||15,862||167.36||90.17 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Stenungsund Municipality|Stenungsund]]||10||26,325||251.91||100.08 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Lilla Edet Municipality|Lilla Edet]]||11||13,948||316.23||41.05 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Alingsås Municipality|Alingsås]]||12||40,566||472.03||82.86 |-align=right bgcolor=#ffffdd |align=left|[[Kungsbacka Municipality|Kungsbacka]]||13||82,382||606.67||128.73 |-align=left bgcolor=#ffffdd !align=left|Total!!13!!'''1,015,974'''!!3,694.86!!262.25 |} {{note label|3|1}} km2
{{note label|4|2}} Population per km2
 ==Metropolitan Malmö== [[File:Metropolitan Malmö ver.1.PNG|right|thumb|350px]] [[File:Malmo view2.jpg|right|thumb|350px|The Øresund strait between Malmö and Copenhagen with Malmö in the foreground and the island of Amager and part of southern Copenhagen in the background]] '''Greater Malmö''' (''Stormalmö''), also known as '''Metropolitan Malmö''' is the [[metropolitan area]] of [[Malmö]] in [[Sweden]]. The area is located in Southwestern [[Scania]] (''Sydvästra Skåne''), which is often considered synonymous with Greater Malmö, and it is part of the wider transnational [[Greater Copenhagen (metropolitan region)|Öresund Region]]. Besides Malmö, large towns in Greater Malmö includes [[Lund]] and [[Trelleborg]], the former of which was the seat of the historical [[Diocese of Lund#Catholic History|Catholic Archdiocese of Lund]]. Since the [[1970s]], improvements in [[highway]]s and the [[Pågatåg|regional]] and [[Øresundståg|InterRegio]] train networks means the commuting area has grown to include [[Ystad]], [[Skurup]], [[Sjöbo]], [[Eslöv]], [[Höör]], [[Landskrona]] and [[Helsingborg]], though only some of these are included in official definitions of Greater Malmö. It's not uncommon to live in Malmö and work either in Ystad or Helsingborg, or vice versa, but these towns have kept their mental allegiance with older divisions of Scania. Commuting across the [[Øresund|Öresund]] has become more common, both through the [[Øresund Bridge]] and the [[HH Ferry route]], at which car ferries departs every 12 minutes in summer (every 15 minutes in winter). [[Statistics Sweden]], which sets the official definitions for all metropolitan areas in Sweden, has changed which [[Municipalities of Sweden|municipalities]] are included in Greater Malmö over time. The most recent change to the definition came in 2006, when [[Eslöv Municipality|Eslöv]], [[Höör Municipality|Höör]], and [[Skurup Municipality|Skurup]] Municipalities became part of Greater Malmö, bringing the number of municipalities included from 9 to 12. ===Statistics=== {| class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align:right" |-bgcolor=#dddddd ! Municipality !! Number !! Population !! Area{{efn|name=data|Area is in km2, density is in people per km2}}!! revision.text:
{{Montenegro topics sidebar}}
This is a '''list of populated places in [[Montenegro]]''', sorted by [[Municipalities of Montenegro|municipality]]. Places with more than 1,000 residents are shown in ''italics''. For each settlement with a significant [[Albanians|Albanian]] population, the [[Albanian language|Albanian]] name for the settlement is given after a forward-slash (/).

revision.text:
[[File:Mimmo Rotella, Pierre Restany, Filippo Panseca.jpg|thumb|Mimmo Rotella with the art critic Pierre Restany and Filippo Panseca]] '''Domenico "Mimmo" Rotella''', ([[Catanzaro]], 7 October 1918 – [[Milan]], 8 January 2006), was an [[Italy|Italian]] [[artist]] considered an important figure in post-war European art. Best known for his works of [[décollage]] and [[psychogeographics]], made from torn advertising posters. He was associated to the [[Ultra-Lettrists]] an offshoot of [[Lettrism]] and later was a member of the ''[[Nouveau realisme|Nouveau Réalisme]]'', founded in 1960 by the art critic [[Pierre Restany]].
==Biography==
=== 1918-1951 === After finishing school studies he moves to [[Naples]] in 1933 to pursue his artistic studies, but he got a job at the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications. In 1941, he moved to [[Rome]]. He remains in the capital only for a short period, because he is called up. In 1944 he left the army and he graduated from the Art School of Naples. Between 1944 and 1945 he teaches drawing in [[Catanzaro]]. In 1945 he returned to Rome and, following his figurative beginnings and first experimentations, he began to paint new-geometric paintings. He starts in 1947 to participate at the exhibition, with the Exhibition Board of Fine Arts and the annual Art Club. In 1949 he devoted himself to the phonetic poetry experiments, calling epistaltic (a meaningless neologism), which in the same year he draws up the Manifesto (published by L.Sinisgalli in "Civilization of machines")
=== 1951-1953 === In 1951 he had his first contact with French art, exhibiting in [[Paris]] at the Salon des [[Nouveau réalisme|Nouvelles Réalités]]. Between 1951 and 1952, he obtained the award of a scholarship from the [[Fulbright Foundation]], which allows him to travel to the US as an "Artist in Residence" at the University of Kansas City. Also in 1952 he realized the second personal exhibithion at the Rockhill Nelson Gallery in Kansas City. In the United States he had the opportunity to meet representatives of the new artistic currents: [[Robert Rauschenberg]], [[Claes Oldenburg]], [[Cy Twombly]], [[Jackson Pollock]] and [[Yves Klein]].
=== 1953 === In 1953, he suffers from an artistic crisis, during which interrupts his pictorial production. Now convinced that there is nothing to be done again in art, suddenly what he calls "Zen illumination": the discovery of the advertising poster as artistic expression of the city. Thus the [[décollage]] (early collages) was born: paste on canvas pieces of torn posters of the street, by adopting the collages of the [[Cubism|cubists]] and contaminating it with [[Dada]]ist array of [[Found object|ready made]]. In 1955, in Rome, in the exhibition "actual art exhibition", he exhibited for the first time the 'torn poster'. Later, he practiced the so-called double décollage: the poster firstly removed from the billboard, then torn up in his studio. In those years he also made use of the retro d'affiche, using the posters pasted on the side and obtaining non-figurative and [[Monochrome painting|monochrome]] works.
=== 1953-1960 === The first awards arrive in 1956 with the Graziano Award and in 1957 with the Battistoni Prize and Public Education. With the [[Cinecittà]] series of 1958, select figures and faces of film advertising directing production toward more figurative works. At the end of the Fifties, Rotella, is labeled by critics as a ripper or painter of glued paper. At night, tearing not only posters but also pieces of sheet metal from frames of the billboard zones of the Rome Municipality. In 1958 he receives in Rome the visit of the French critic [[Pierre Restany]], with whom he began a long association. In the same year he participated in Rome in the exhibition "New Italian art trends" organized by [[Lionello Venturi]] in the seat of Rome - New York Art Foundation. The curiosity of the public for the artist's extravagances, culminated in 1960 with the creation, the work of Enzo Nasso, a short film dedicated to angry Painters, which cure Rotella spoken commentary.
=== 1960-1980 === Also in 1960 he joined the [[Nouveau réalisme|New Realism]] - but he didn't sign the manifesto - theorist of which [[Pierre Restany]] and bringing together, among others, [[Yves Klein]], [[Daniel Spoerri|Spoerri]], [[Jean Tinguely|Tinguely]], César, [[Arman]] and [[Christo and Jeanne-Claude|Christo]]. The group will also take part in the French [[Raymond Hains|Hains]], Dufrêne and [[Jacques Villeglé|Villeglé]], operating on [[décollage]] in the same years, but independently. Together with décollages, Rotella also performs assemblage of objects bought from junk dealers as bottle caps or cords. [[Pop art|Pop Art]] and [[Abstract expressionism|Abstract Expressionism]], with the Informal and the spatial and material research in those years, [[Lucio Fontana]] and [[Alberto Burri]] taking place in Italy, they play an important role in the orientation of Rotella. In 1961 he composed a historical exhibition À 40 ° au-dessus de Dada, edited in Paris by Restany. In 1962 he gives a presentation on his art at the [[School of Visual Arts]] in New York and in 1964 he was invited to the [[Venice Biennale]] and, in 1965, the IX Quadrennial of Rome. Using typographic tools, between 1967 and 1973 he created his Art-typo, prints chosen and reproduced freely on the canvas. This procedure is able to overlap and superimpose advertising images, reversing the previous approach. In the early seventies produces some works by intervening on the advertising pages of magazines with the use of solvents and reducing or state at the imprint (frottage) or deleting one (effaçage). In 1972, he published his autobiography entitled Autorotella. In 1975 he recorded his first disc of phonetic poetry and in 1976 he took part in the "International Poetry Recital Sonora - Poetry Action". Another trial, in those years, it is that of rolling up posters and closing them in plexiglass cubes.
=== 1980-2006 === Finally he left Paris to settle in [[Milan]] (1980), in the eighties he processes the "blanks" or affiches covers: zeroed advertising posters covered with white sheets, as with the expired advertisement. In 1984 he made the second cycle of works dedicated to the cinema: Cinecittà 2. After 1986 he realizes 'Sovrapitture', inspired by graffiti: intervenes pictorially of torn poster glued on canvas. It drew anonymous writings, such as those that can be read on city walls: love notes and political slogans, etc., in a double message. In 1990 he participated at the [[Centre Georges Pompidou|Centre Pompidou]] in Paris in the exhibition "Art et Pub" and the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in [[New York City|New York]] exhibition "High and Low". He married in 1991 with the Russian Inna Agarounova, and in 1993 they had a child called Asya. In 1992 from the French Minister of Culture, [[Jack Lang (French politician)|Jack Lang]], he receives the title of 'Officiel des arts et des Lettres'. A foundation dedicated to him was established in 2000, to the artist's will: the 'Fondazione Mimmo Rotella', with the aim of collecting the works and documents cataloged in the artistic life of the teacher. In 2004 Rotella received an honorary degree in Architecture at the University Mediterranea of [[Reggio Calabria]].
He was invited to the [[New York City|New York]] [[List of Guggenheim Museums|Guggenheim Museum]] in 1994 for the exhibition "Italian Metamorphosis", then again at the Centre Pompidou in 1996 in "Face à l'Histoire", and in 1996 the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles in "Halls of Mirrors "exhibition subsequently exported all over the world. The [[Federico Fellini]] film dedicates the series of works called Fellini.
He died in Milan on January 8, 2006 at the age of 88 years.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2016-11-09|title=Mimmo Rotella|url=https://it.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mimmo_Rotella&oldid=84212670|journal=Wikipedia|language=it}}</ref>
==Artwork==
=== Décollages === [[Décollage]] is an artistic technique of collage to the opposite procedure. Instead of adding elements of the work, it starts from an artistic object from which the parts are detached. The idea of decollage was born during a period of "artistic crisis" and took place following the trip to the US, during which he was in contact with members of the [[Neo-Dada|New Dada]]. Back in Rome he became inspired by torn posters around the town and began to carry them in his studio and to work on them. The result was the creation of canvases on which pasted wheel one or more pieces of torn posters, often superimposed. Rotella wanted to somehow find some form of artistic innovation and at the same time give artistic dignity to a common object, and of little value removed from its natural environment. The first trials of Rotella with decollage date back to 1953. The first decollage, in most small cases, were exhibited for the first time in the spring of 1955.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2016-11-09|title=Mimmo Rotella|url=https://it.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mimmo_Rotella&oldid=84212670|journal=Wikipedia|language=it}}</ref>
=== Retro d'affiches === The two roads that Rotella takes on simultaneously, starting in 1953-1954 are those of decollage and retro posters. The first retro d'affiche documented date back to 1954. The retro d'affiche are displayed for the first time to the public in December 1955 at the personal exhibition the artist held at the Galleria del Naviglio in [[Milan]]. Unlike decollage where often textural layers are wrapped together and manipulated, in the back of posters the artist retains the "urban relic". In these works his speech tends to be subtle, the colors are often absent, the surface is gritty and raw, it has compared to decollage a more targeted research to informal language, except that it will become evident starting especially from the sixties when decollages in expected to bet influenced by the rising [[Pop art|pop language]].<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2016-11-09|title=Mimmo Rotella|url=https://it.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mimmo_Rotella&oldid=84212670|journal=Wikipedia|language=it}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Mimmo Rotella: Decollages e retro d'affiches|last=Germano|first=Celant|publisher=SKIRA|year=2014|isbn=978-88-572-2328-5|location=Milan|pages=35–38|quote=|via=}}</ref>

Celant (a cura di), Mimmo Rotella. Décollages e retro d'affiches, Skira, Milan 2014 * Poesie der Großstadt. Die Affichisten''. Bernard Blistène, Fritz Emslander, Esther Schlicht, Didier Semin, Dominique Stella. Snoeck, Köln 2014<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fondazionemimmorotella.net/bibliografia.html|title=Fondazione Mimmo Rotella {{!}} Bibliografia|website=www.fondazionemimmorotella.net|access-date=2016-11-09}}</ref>
== Recordings== * ''Poemi fonetici 1949-75'', Plura Records, Milan 1975. * ''Rotella variations'', in collaboration with Tiziana Ghiglioni, Enrico Rava, Emanuele Parrini, Gianluigi Troversi, Giancarlo Schiaffini, Claudio Fasoli, Dimitri Grechi Espinoza, Jacopo Martini, Franco Nesti, [[Tiziano Tononi]], Splasc(h), Arcisate 2003.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fondazionemimmorotella.net/biblio_disco.html|title=Fondazione Mimmo Rotella {{!}} Bibliografia|website=www.fondazionemimmorotella.net|access-date=2016-11-09}}</ref>
==Cinema==
* L'ora della lucertola, directed by Mimmo Calopestri (2004)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fondazionemimmorotella.net/cinema.html|title=Fondazione Rotella {{!}} Cinema su Rotella|website=www.fondazionemimmorotella.net|access-date=2016-11-09}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060112121446/http://www.mimmorotella.it/ Official website] * [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/13/arts/design/13rotella.html Obituary] in the ''New York Times'', USA, 13 January 2006 * [http://news.independent.co.uk/people/obituaries/article337980.ece Obituary] in the ''Independent'', UK, by [[James Kirkup]] 12 January 2006 * [http://ansa.it/main/notizie/awnplus/english/news/2006-01-09_2309100.html Obituary]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} in ANSA, Italy, 9 January 2006 * [http://arasgallery.com/profile.php?id=33 Aras Gallery Biography]

[[File:Summit camp Everest.jpg|thumb|290px|Everest from the South Col, 2013]]
The '''Mount Everest''' climbing season of '''2013''' included 658 summits and 8 deaths.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.alanarnette.com/blog/2013/06/03/everest-2013-season-recap/|title=Everest 2013: Season Recap: Summits, Records and Fights|date=2013-06-03|work=The Blog on alanarnette.com|access-date=2017-07-16|language=en-US}}</ref> Due to avalanches in [[2014 Mount Everest ice avalanche|2014]] and [[2015 Mount Everest avalanches|2015]], this was the last big summiting year until 2016.
==2013 mountaineering season==
{| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin-right: 0; margin-left: 1em;" |+Years in Review Summary |- !Year !Summiters !Reference(s) |- |[[Mount Everest in 2012|2012]] |547 <!--NGO says 547 in there table--> |<ref name="NG - Maxed Out on Everest">{{cite web|url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2013/06/125-everest-maxed-out/jenkins-text |title=Everest Maxed Out |publisher=ngm.nationalgeographic.com|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> |- style="background: red; color: white" <!--style="background:#efefef;"--> |2013 |658 |<ref name="alanarnette">{{cite web|url=http://www.alanarnette.com/blog/2013/06/03/everest-2013-season-recap/|title=Everest 2013: Season Recap: Summits, Records and Fights|publisher=alanarnette.com|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> |- |[[2014 Mount Everest ice avalanche|2014]] |106 |<ref name="alanarnette2">{{cite web|url=http://www.alanarnette.com/blog/2014/06/09/everest-2014-season-summary-nepal-tragedy/|title=Everest 2014: Season Summary - A Nepal Tragedy|publisher=alanarnette.com|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> |- style="background:#efefef;" |[[2015 Mount Everest avalanches|2015]] |0 |<ref name="washingtonpost">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/01/12/for-the-first-time-in-42-years-nobody-made-it-to-the-top-of-mount-everest-last-year/ |title= The Washington Post - For the first time in four decades, nobody made it to the top of Mount Everest last year|author= Peter Holley|date=12 January 2016 |publisher=washingtonpost.com|accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> |- |2016 |641 | <reF>[http://www.alanarnette.com/blog/2016/12/30/everest-by-the-numbers-2017-edition/]</ref> |} [[File:U.S. Air Force Capt. Colin Merrin, assigned to the 2nd Space Operations Squadron, hikes the summit of Mount Everest in Nepal May 20, 2013 130520-F-ZZ999-001.jpg|thumb|Another view from around the South Col area up toward the higher elevations of Everest, on 20 May 2013]] The 2013 Himalayan Database recorded 658 summits, which brought the total number to 6,871 by 4,042 different persons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.alanarnette.com/blog/2014/02/20/everest-numbers-latest-summit-stats/ |title=Everest by the Numbers: The Latest Summit Stats |last1=Arnette |first1=Alan |last2= |first2= |date=20 February 2014 |website=The Himalayan Database|access-date=21 September 2016}}</ref> The year's total was greater than 2007's 633 summiters, the previous yearly record.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/05/26/travel/everest-by-the-numbers/|title=Mount Everest: By the numbers|work=CNN}}</ref>
In 2013, [[Yuichiro Miura]] became the oldest person to reach the summit, at age 80.<ref>{{cite news|title=Japanese Octogenarian Becomes Oldest Man to Reach Summit of Mount Everest|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/japanese-octogenarian-oldest-man-reach-summit-mount-everest/story?id=19238945#.UZ4v3qK1HxA|work=ABC News|accessdate=23 May 2013}}</ref>
A Eurocopter AS350 B3 flown by Maurizio Folini achieved a record breaking rescue at {{convert|7800|m|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} on the morning of 21 May, retrieving [[Sudarshan Gautam]], who was descending the mountain after becoming the first person without arms to summit Everest without using prosthetics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.verticalmag.com/press-releases/maurizio-folini-named-pilot-of-highest-helicopter-rescue-on/|title=Maurizio Folini named pilot of highest helicopter rescue on Everest - Vertical Magazine|work=Vertical Magazine|access-date=2017-07-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.calgarysun.com/2013/05/20/armless-calgary-man-sudarshan-gautam-reaches-dream-of-summitting-mount-everest|title=Armless Calgary man Sudarshan Gautam reaches dream of summitting Mount Everest|website=Calgary Sun|access-date=2017-07-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304113725/http://www.calgarysun.com/2013/05/20/armless-calgary-man-sudarshan-gautam-reaches-dream-of-summitting-mount-everest|archivedate=2016-03-04|df=}}</ref> Gautam was rescued after collapsing near Camp 3.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rockandice.com/climbing-news/daring-high-altitude-rescue-on-everest-sets-records|title=Daring High Altitude Rescue on Everest Sets Records|website=www.rockandice.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-16}}</ref>
On 21 May, [[Arunima Sinha]] became the first female amputee to summit Everest.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/22/arunima-sinha-first-female-amputee-everest_n_3317252.html|title=Arunima Sinha, Indian Woman, Is First Female Amputee To Climb Everest|last=Presse|first=Agence France|date=2013-05-22|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-07-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
[[Phurba Tashi]] completed his 21st summit in May, a total equal to the record held by [[Apa Sherpa]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/south-asia/Phurba-Tashi-climbs-Everest-for-21st-time-equals-record/articleshow/20237259.cms|title=Phurba Tashi climbs Everest for 21st time, equals record - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2017-07-16}}</ref>
==Assault on climbers==
On 27 April, three climbers were attacked by a group of 100 Sherpas at 21,000 feet elevation.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/nepal/10037481/What-drove-100-Sherpas-to-attack-Western-climbers-on-Everest.html|title=What drove 100 Sherpas to attack Western climbers on Everest?}}</ref> The event was seen as an aberration in the otherwise decades-long spirit of teamwork and friendship on the mountain.<ref name="ReferenceC" /> Sherpas have a reputation for going to extraordinary lengths for climbers, and being generous in sharing Everest with visitors to Nepal.<ref name="dailymail.co.uk" />
Earlier in the day, a group of three climbers on the Lhotse Face had crossed over lines being laid by the Sherpas, contrary to the etiquette that climbers should avoid Sherpas working on the mountain.<ref name="ReferenceC" /> Words were exchanged and the situation escalated. An ice pick was brandished and ice and stones were thrown. The Sherpas then left the Lhotse Face, but later visited the camp site with about 100 others and threatened to kill one of the three climbers. The climber was upset because he considered himself a friend of the Sherpa community, had built a school for nearly 400 Sherpa children, and also had funded free evacuations via helicopters for Sherpas.<ref name="fight">{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/13/130502-mount-everest-fight-simone-moro-interview-sherpas/|title=Everest Climber: Sherpas Tried to Kill Me|work=National Geographic |access-date= 21 September 2016}}</ref><ref name="outsideonline.com">{{cite journal|url=http://www.outsideonline.com/1929351/everest-brawl-sherpas-tale |title=The Everest Brawl: A Sherpa's Tale |last1=Adhikari |first1=Deepak|date=13 August 2013 |work=Outside |access-date=22 September 2016}}</ref> {{quote|'I came here to climb Mt. Everest. I came here for the challenge, adventure and type of friendship that has become a mark of this place for me. On this expedition, I have had some of the best times of my life, laughing into the late hours with friends who were supporting each other's goals. I have had some of the worst times — standing in front of those same friends to protect them from unexplainable violence and anger. Something shifted the balance for a moment. My only hope is that it shifts back quickly, and everyone can resume their jobs, their passion and their goal of climbing.|M. Arnot on the 2013 Everest season attack<ref name="dailymail.co.uk"/>}}
The American climber [[Melissa Arnot]] helped defuse the fight.<ref name="dailymail.co.uk" /> The 29-year-old Arnot placed herself between the attackers and the climbers.<ref name="dailymail.co.uk">{{cite journal |last1=Brooke |first1=Chris |last2=Golgowski |first2=Nina |date= |title=Revealed: The female American climber, 29, who heroically broke up vicious fight between 'more than 100 Sherpas and three hikers with calm talk and hand holding|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2317417/Melissa-Arnot-Meet-American-climber-broke-fight-Sherpas-hikers-Mt-Everest.html |work=Daily Mail |volume= |issue=1 May 2013 |access-date=21 September 2016 }}</ref> She had friendly relationships with both the climbers and the high-altitude Sherpas, and managed to bring a halt to the fighting. She then negotiated a truce between the mountaineers.<ref name="dailymail.co.uk" />
The Nepalese government said if climbers were attacked, action would be taken against the aggressors.<ref name="cnn.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/04/29/world/asia/nepal-mount-everest-fight/|title=A fight at 23,000 feet? Climbers accuse Sherpas of Mount Everest attack}}</ref> An official from the [[Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation (Nepal)|Nepal tourism ministry]] described the attack as a misunderstanding that had been sorted out and pledged to ensure the safety of climbers. The three ringleaders of the attack were removed from the mountain.<ref name="dailymail.co.uk" /> Sherpas are renowned for the most part for their climbing skill and demeanour, with one Everest climber noting, "To a man everyone seems to be absolutely impressed with the Sherpas. Not just their strength on the mountain, which is legendary, but their personalities and their friendliness. They become your friends."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://netnebraska.org/article/news/1029247/nebraskan-climbed-mount-everest%E2%80%A6and-it-almost-killed-him |title=A Nebraskan climbed Mount Everest...and it almost killed him |last1=Tobias |first1=Mike |last2= |first2= |date=22 June 2016 |website=Net Nebraska |access-date=22 September 2016}}</ref> The fight led to improved communication between the people on the mountain, which helped to overcome the cultural and language barriers that complicated an already difficult environment.<ref name="outsideonline.com" />
==Fatalities== There were 8 fatalities attributed to mountaineering.<ReF>[http://www.alanarnette.com/blog/2013/06/03/everest-2013-season-recap/]</ref> One of the losses was the well-known and respected climber, Alexi Bolotov, who died in the Khumbu Icefall when the rope he was rappelling down broke.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.outsideonline.com/1797216/alex-bolotov-dies-everest|title=Alex Bolotov Dies on Everest|last=Rosenfield|first=Scott|date=2013-05-15|work=Outside Online|access-date=2017-05-23|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Mount Everest}}
[[Category:Mount Everest]] [[Category:2013 in Nepal]] [[Category:History of mountaineering]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Северна България.png|right|thumb|350px|Northern Bulgaria]]
'''Northern Bulgaria''' ({{lang-bg|Северна България}}, ''Severna Balgariya''), also called '''Moesia''' ({{lang-bg|Мизия}}, ''Miziya'') is the northern half of the territory of [[Bulgaria]], located to the north of the main ridge of the [[Balkan Mountains]] which conventionally separates the country into a northern and a southern part. Besides the Balkan Mountains, Northern Bulgaria borders the [[Timok River]] and [[Serbia]] to the west, the [[Danube River]] and [[Romania]] to the north and the [[Bulgarian Black Sea Coast]] to the east.
Geographically, the [[terrain]] is relatively uniform, dominated by the hilly [[Danubian Plain (Bulgaria)|Danubian Plain]], with some low [[plateau]]s to the east. Northern Bulgaria covers an area of 48,596 square kilometres and has a population of 2,674,347 according to the 2011 census<ref>[http://www.nsi.bg/ORPDOCS/Census2011_1.pop_by_age.xls Population by province, municipality, settlement and age by 01.02.2011; Bulgarian National Statistical Institute] {{bg icon}}</ref> (36% of Bulgaria's entire population), with a [[population density]] of 55 people per km². The three largest cities are [[Varna]], [[Rousse]] and [[Pleven]].
Administratively, Northern Bulgaria includes the following 14 [[Provinces of Bulgaria|Bulgarian provinces]]:
* [[Dobrich Province]] * [[Gabrovo Province]] * [[Lovech Province]] * [[Montana Province]] * [[Pleven Province]] * [[Razgrad Province]] * [[Rousse Province]] * [[Shumen Province]] * [[Silistra Province]] * [[Targovishte Province]] * [[Varna Province]] * [[Veliko Tarnovo Province]] * [[Vidin Province]] * [[Vratsa Province]]
Parts of [[Burgas Province]], [[Sliven Province]], and [[Sofia Province]] also geographically belong to Northern Bulgaria.
Northern Bulgaria covers the historical region of [[Moesia]], which in turn includes several sub-regions such as [[Southern Dobruja|Dobruja]] (sometimes not considered part of Moesia), [[Ludogorie]], [[Gerlovo]] and [[Zlatiya (region)|Zlatiya]]. Northern Bulgaria is also conventionally divided into [[Severozapaden|Northwestern]], [[Severen tsentralen|Central Northern]] and [[Severoiztochen|Northeastern]] Bulgaria, with slightly varying borders. The lower northern reaches of the Balkan Mountains are called the [[Fore-Balkan]], as opposed to the [[Sub-Balkan valleys]] to the south of the main ridge. In Antiquity, the [[Jireček Line]] divided [[Latin]] (in the north) and [[Ancient Greek]] (in the south) language influence in the [[Balkans]], with Northern Bulgaria to the north of it and Southern Bulgaria to the south. Much later, after the [[Liberation of Bulgaria]] in 1878, all of Northern Bulgaria and the region of [[Sofia]] became the [[Principality of Bulgaria]] while most of the rest of Southern Bulgaria was part of [[Eastern Rumelia]] until the [[Bulgarian unification]] in 1885.
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:Dobrudja.JPG|The fertile plains of [[Dobruja]] File:Danube at belene.jpg|The [[Danube]] at [[Belene]] Image:Overview of village Turgovishte.jpg|A village in the northwestern reaches of the [[Balkan Mountains]] Image:Cape Galata, Varna.JPG|The [[Bulgarian Black Sea Coast]] near [[Varna]] </gallery>
==See also== * [[Southern Bulgaria]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * {{cite web |url=http://grao.bg/tna/tab01.html |title=Таблица на населението по постоянен и настоящ адрес |language=Bulgarian |accessdate=2009-07-21 |publisher=Главна Дирекция Гражданска Регистрация и Административно Обслужване }}<!-- Настоящ адрес -->
==External links== {{portalbar|Bulgaria}}
{{Wikivoyage|North Bulgaria}}
{{coord missing|Bulgaria}}
[[Category:Geography of Bulgaria]] [[Category:Historical regions in Bulgaria]]
